title: Entrepreneurs frustrated at Government's lack of support
text:

Mon, Oct 19, 2015, 05:28 BST - UK Markets open in 2 hrs 32 mins Entrepreneurs frustrated at Government's lack of support By Elizabeth Anderson | Telegraph – 4 hours ago 0.00 
In a poll of business owners, many are disappointed over new tax changes 
A lack of confidence in the global economy, changes to taxes on dividends, and the introduction of the new national living wage have all contributed to a drop in confidence among small businesses. 
Some 70pc of entrepreneurs believe the government is committed to supporting private enterprise, a drop of 10 percentage points in three months, according to the latest quarterly Enterprise Index from accountants Smith & Williamson, which surveyed around 200 UK-based entrepreneurs. 
The authors said that while entrepreneurs are broadly supportive of the Conservative government, they are disappointed at recent changes seen as being unfriendly to small businesses. 
These changes include the new dividend tax due in next April (LSE: 0N69.L - news ) , which means basic-rate taxpayers will have to pay tax on dividend income for the first time. 
It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) comes at a time when small businesses are already preparing for rising costs with the introduction of the national living wage, which means all workers aged 25 and over will earn a minimum of £7.20 an hour from April next year. 
Entrepreneurs also cited frustration over changes to investment rules for venture capital trusts (VCT) earlier this year, which caps the amount of money a company can receive from a VCT to £15m, or £20m for knowledge intensive companies. 
“These VCT changes have been forced on us by the EU and they’re limiting the amount of money a business can raise for acquisitions and buyouts. While it’s been forced upon on the UK, the feeling is that perhaps the Treasury hasn’t been too terribly robust in its defence. It will slow the finance opportunities for companies and is not helpful,” said Guy Rigby, partner and head of entrepreneurial services at Smith & Williamson. 
However, he added business owners are overwhelmingly supportive of the Conservative party and said the Labour party has a major credibility problem following the election of left-leaning Jeremy Corbyn as leader. 
There are fears his theory of printing more money to fund more spending projects could disrupt the still-stabilising economy, said Mr Rigby. 
The survey also suggested 90pc of entrepreneurs would consider launching a crowdfunding to raise money. A lack of confidence in banks means crowdfunding is now considered an important way of raising funds, Smith & Williamson said.
